Normally I don´t post negative comments, but in THIS case, I have to speak out how I feel about Spacetourism and particulary Virgin Galactic.

To me it is insane to abuse our planet and it´s fragile upper atmosphere lighthearted with the pollution of solid-rocket-gases, wich are extremely poisonous for a cheap purpose like that! I am strictly against it, and if you watch the traces of pollution in those 40k plus feet altitude, I feel deeply sorry for what we as a species come up with just to make a funpark out of our sensitive environment.

Yes, of course, we take our habits and culture everywhere we go. So we expand into space, shoot thousand of satellites into orbit that beam down to the ground, and yes, we will go on fighting wars in space for resources on asteroids and other stellar objects, just as we use to do for millenia here on earth.

But this is different.

Pollution into these upper athmospheres is just insanely more malicious than down on the ground. Our planet belongs to itself, but no one asked for my permission to profitize space for superrich people and pollute my planet. Expanding into space for the sake of tech and inevitable mining and/or expanding consiousness is ethically neutral to me. Spacetourism is definetely not.

If any privat entity uses my planet for private profits, then, at least, use the most environmental neutral propellants, like Blue Origin does or even Spacex. The use of solid rocket boosters should be banned.

Sorry. But this is just so off the track. Shame on this.

1:16:52 I would think the angle on the rocket bell is, as you say, to provide an upwards moment. The thrust vector being above and behind the centre of lift would normally cause a downwards moment, which is probably not what you want at mach 1 and accelerating. The tilted thrust vector would help keep the aircraft in trim and limit the size and travel needed for the control surfaces.

Tim--Having the lower portion of the nozzle canted out helps assist the aerodynamic controls in creating the necessary "control moment" to pitch the nose up in prep for vertical flight. It's also a consideration taken because of the unique launch/burn profile and the various air pressures during the pitch up, which have a steadily receding effect on the control surfaces as it ascends into thinner air. It is roughly analogous to using N2O4 injection into a specific portion of the nozzle for thrust vector control on non-gimballing solid rockets. The flow stays attached longer to the longer (lower) nozzle portion, thus providing a continuous gentle pitch-up until the motor shuts off whilst still in the atmosphere.

I have theory about the shape of the nozzle:

Hasn't Everyday Astronaut already explained that you cannot use Vacuum Merlin engine close to the sea level, because the relatively high pressure outside ambient air can somehow leak into the nozzle, and cause some turbulence effects?

When the Virgin Galatic's spaceship performs that turn where it first goes horizontally, and then turns vertical, during that turn the outside ambient air can probably leak into the nozzle more easily from the top than from bottom. So they cut the top part of the nozzle away to avoid that turbulence?

About the cut on the nozzle, aerodynamic surfaces are to small to control the pitch of the ship when a standard shape nozzle outputs its forward thrust. The “cut” increases upward pitch authority. Great live stream Tim 🙌

HISTORY OF SPACEPLANES


Where is the Virgin Galactic’s comparison and analysis with the historical development of rocket propelled spaceplanes over 60+ years in the space community?

I was surprised there has not been any comparison with historical developments and achievements of rocket propelled spaceplanes, in particular the X-15 of the 1960’s and how significant the achievement Virgin Galactic’s SpaceShip Two plays in the future of spaceplanes.

From 1962 – 1968 the X-15 exceed an attitude of 50 km during 13 flights therefore meeting the US standard for sub-orbital space flight. Two (2) flights exceeded the international standard Karman line of 100 km: 105.9 km and 107.8 km, respectively capable of orbital flight.

Now, 60+ years later we have successful flights of a spaceplane carrying multiple human occupants. While Virgin Orbit is successful at economically placing small satellites in, orbit, it’s still not a spaceplane and reusable (with limited recognition of their accomplishments).

Though we have the technology and expertise to achieve orbit with a reusable spaceplane, will we ever see the space industry allocate sufficient resources to make it happen? Or are our current leaders in the space industry still living in politics, legacy mentality, lack vison, and innovation for the future of space flight?

US AND INTERNATIONAL REQUIREMENTS FOR ASTRONAUT WINGS

Here's the [general] clarification for issuing ASTRONAUT WINGS from Wikipedia: "The criteria for what constitutes human spaceflight vary, with some focus on the point where the atmosphere becomes so thin that centrifugal force, rather than aerodynamic force, carries a significant portion of the weight of the flight object. The Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (FAI) Sporting Code for astronautics recognizes only flights that exceed the Kármán line, at an altitude of 100 kilometers (62 mi).

In the United States, professional, military, and commercial astronauts who travel above an altitude of 50 miles (80 km) are awarded astronaut wings."

Astronaut Wings have been awarded based on 2 flight categories:

1) Orbital flight
2) Sub-orbital flight of a rocket propelled spaceplane. The first awards were to some pilots of the X-15 rocket spaceplane back in the 1960's.

US eligibility, besides exceeding 80 km, assumes that the person completes the related training program qualifying them to fly their missions. There is no standardized training or credentialing requirements, it's up to the individual organization.

The crew of Virgin Galactic SpaceShipTwo meets current requirements for astronaut wings:

1) Exceeding 80 km in either orbital or sub-orbital flight
2) They all are professional employees of Virgin Galactic with specific responsibilities relating to the mission, and they completed the required training to perform their in-flight mission objectives. They are not armatures, or loosely defined space tourists, and do not have to be narrowly defined as pilots, scientists, engineers, etc.


With space tourism in its infancy and a new emerging travel category, not only will there be new professional job categories (employment opportunities), but there needs to be a new classification for "space tourist" in order not to diminish the contributions of professional astronauts.

colbert cringe

Today, July 11th 2021, the world changed.

For the first time in recorded history, a for-profit company launched human beings from the planet's surface to touch the surly bonds of Earth and gently return.

No wars will end. No life will be saved. But, we now live under a different sky on a different planet in a different era.

My daughter is 3, and for the first time in her life, I can look up to the sky and say "You can go there, sweety."

And that's a pretty cool thing.

To those that say that the American definition of the boundary of Space is invalid (as opposed to the international official definition), I say watch the Scott Manley video about it. The American definition of Space (50 miles) is as valid as the other. The craft needs thrusters to control attitude and no longer has an ability to use aerodynamic controls. They are appreciably outside the atmosphere. As for those haters that say it is not a space trip but a glorified fun ride, Joe Engle and Bill Dana likely would have disagreed with you. (They were X-15 pilots). Going into space in a PLANE is actually kind of dangerous and requires impressive piloting skills. (One of the X-15 pilots died in 1967 due to a control failure.) I am really impressed that Burt Rutan designed a method to keep the vehicle stable during reentry into the atmosphere.
I am stoked! (Also, I am a Virgin Galactic stockholder. Looking forward to a nice bounce!)

For a company like United Airlines, or in this case Virgin Airlines, this is a postive move in the aviation industry. Moving people from one place to another. Unlike other airlines, Virgin Corporate had invested heavily in developing a cost effective safe and practical system to achieve this goal. We are not talking about Spacex, which is a multi-billion dollar company developing transportation to the Moon and Mars with NASA government funding. Virgin Airlines is clearly here on Earth working exclusively towards their future airline business goals. This is a first step in the process. Once their technology is proven effective and reliable, they will be offering practical one-to-two hour service from New York to London, Los Angeles to Tokyo, and other key destinations in the World for business travelers, no time-waisting space suit required. Over time if all goes well, they will develop larger like-vehicles to accommodate more passingers at a reduced reasionable cost. I believe that is their business plan in the Airline Industry. Forget about todays marketing hype, thats just to gain a return on their business investment in engineering their first suborbital transportation vehicle.

The asymmetrical nozzle is probably to have a lower center of thrust that is needed for the correct balance of the total vehicle. The aerodynamics also need to taken into account for the descent glide. I can imagine there is a limit of where the engine can be mounted, so if it is still too high for the correct thrust balance, the nozzle can lower the thrust a bit.

I've read SpaceX's target for the cost to launch a Starship to orbit is $2 million per launch. Lets assume they hit that target and lets assume it can reasonably accommodate 100 passengers for a short duration. You could easily see $30-40k per ticket orbital flights. That is still a hefty sum of money for most people, but for a day or a few in orbit, it is in the ballpark of what middle class people could be willing to pay for a once in a lifetime experience.

Even if it were $10 million per launch for SpaceX, and the ticket costs were comparable to Virgin Galactic's, even a few hours in orbit is a far better experience than a few minutes of weightlessness on the edge of space.

I did a quick google search and could not confirm.  Is this a viable way to launch payload to lower orbit?  I think when this concept was originally proposed by Burt Rutan, there was a hope that this might be a more efficient way to deliver payloads to orbit.  Is this still the hope or has it been debunked?  Otherwise, it's just a nice toy.    In the context of altitude, U2 is flying at 70,000ft, SR-71 is about 85K ft., X-15 has a record of 354,200 ft (107.96 km),  Startlink is at 340Km, ISS is at 250 miles.  So, 282,000 ft is a pretty high-flying thrill ride but still far short from VLEO.

Not meaning to sound like sour grapes here, but a couple of comments… 1) Even Spaceship One, Spaceship Two’s predecessor, HAD to pass the Karman Line to win the X Prize. (Heck, it’s tail number was N328KF for 328,000 feet/100 km).  No Karman Line, no space.  Imagine the Russians’ very public glee if Alan Shepard only reached 80km!   2) Handing out “Astronaut Wings” to anyone simply willing/able to shell out the money for an elaborate roller coaster ride cheapens the title of “Astronaut” and is an insult to those who genuinely earned that title.  You don’t get “pilot wings” and get to call yourself “pilot” if you buy a ticket and fly as an airline passenger… unless you’re 10 years old and a crew member hands you some plastic wings.
